Award.AwardTitle: Household-Level Use of Autonomous Vehicles: Modeling Framework, Traveler Adaptation, and Infrastructure to Mitigate Negative Effects

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
With recent development in vehicle automation, the idea of sharing public roads with Autonomous Vehicles (AVs) or self-driving vehicles has been widely accepted. Adoption of AVs will drastically change the current picture of the transportation system. One of the areas that is expected to be greatly transformed is vehicle use, travel behavior, and subsequently vehicle ownership from the driverless operations. Yet, there exists no framework to forecast such behavior, demand, and systemic changes at this stage. First, this research will define a framework to simulate and evaluate potential household-level use of AVs from the fundamental notion that travel is a derived demand of individuals' activities and time allocations. Second, this research will develop an infrastructure planning framework, with a focus on parking structure planning, to reduce the potential negative external effects such as increased Vehicle-Mile-Traveled (VMT), congestion, greenhouse gas emissions, etc. The research will enhance understanding of potential issues and external effects as well as policy and infrastructure planning strategies to help reduce the social cost of AV adoption. More broadly, this research will help creating a more sustainable, economic, and efficient transportation and infrastructure system through the AV adoption.

The framework of AV operations is an innovative variation of the Vehicle Routing Problem (VRP) in that (1) it integrates two scheduling and routing problems of travelers and vehicles, and (2) incorporates driverless operations. The novelty of this formulation is that it integrates two routing problems, thus providing routing flexibility for travelers and vehicles. The infrastructure planning framework is modeled through bi-level programming where AV operation decisions are at each household level. A creative modeling approach is introduced to handle the computational challenges. Lastly, a sensitivity analysis will provide insights in understanding changes and challenges in infrastructure, environment, congestion, vehicle ownership, etc. that may arise with the adoption of AVs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this research is to define a framework to model and evaluate potential household-level use of Autonomous Vehicles (AVs), to understand potential issues and negative external effects as well as to provide strategies to mitigate these effects. This project is comprised of two major blocks. First, we develop a model of the decision making schemes of household activities considering the operational dynamics of AVs. A travel decision-making scheme will be defined from the governing rules of activity participation and travel decisions at the household level. Once this decision making scheme is defined, it is then applied to AV operations. Such rules of activity participation and time allocation remain intact for travelers but detached for the vehicles, creating flexibility in vehicle operations. Then, an extension is made to incorporate the use of Shared Autonomous Vehicles (SAVs) taxi systems that are expected to grow significantly with AVs. Solution methods are developed to make the proposed models computationally favorable. Based on an extensive case study and scenario analysis, policy insights on the travel-related utilities on households as well as overall transportation systems (represented as Vehicle-Miles-Traveled (VMT) with a focus of empty VMT), are derived.

In the second phase of the research, a public parking planning model to minimize empty VMT is developed. Instead of AVs going home for parking, public parking facilities encourage AVs to be parked nearby thereby reducing the empty VMT. By nature, this problem is based on a leader-follower (parking locations – private AV uses) structure. However, modeling all individual followers is nearly impossible and computationally expensive. Instead, the parking facility location model is developed to account for AV users’ parking facility usages which can be calibrated. We develop calibration strategies.

This research project provides a framework to understand potential issues and external effects (increased VMT) of owning and operating private AVs in the presence of widely used SAVs. Based on case studies, we have derived insights of policy and public parking facility siting strategies on increased VMT, in particular empty VMT. These findings are expected to help reduce the social cost of AV adoption and more broadly help in creating a more sustainable, economic, and efficient transportation and infrastructure system. In addition, this work has supported three Ph.D. students (including one female student) and two undergraduate students (including one female student) in STEM.
